meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Genia, you're the one that's pioneering it. You've you've

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I think yes, uh, but primarily by having advantages of gentle illumination and relatively rapid access to 3D information.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: And if you start combining that with the smart microscopy type approaches that were described by several groups in our previous brainstorming session, you could imagine situations where you can, you know, screen organoids that are developing in ways that are really efficient and give you a lot of the right kind of information.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, I and I think there are some ways to think about light sheet applications as related to depth, but its primary power is in gentleness and speed and not necessarily in depth.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: But if you think about, you know, broadly light shaping applications, I think would be would have been a better word to put there because light sheet to me it means that you rely somehow on camera based, um, sensor imaging, but light shaping applications are super broad and can rely on point detectors as well as camera based imaging and any kind of sensor that you want. And that's where I think there's a lot of

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: engineering, uh, that relates to depth where you have to kind of think separately about excitation delivery and then also, uh, as as as Sian thinks about a lot also getting back that information out somehow.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Would it be fair to say that the develop continued development of genetic reporters is is going to be key to this as well?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so the more the more colors you can see and the redder the colors you are, this is going to help or are we pretty happy with the genetic reporters that you've got now? I mean,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: No.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a that's a terrific that's a terrific point. Actually, a lot of imaging technologies we're developing now, uh, I was just talking with Genia yesterday about this voltage indicators, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, uh that is one example where it has really strong potential, but it's just not bright enough.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I think genetic reporters could be a very important breaking through point here. So the brightness, right, the efficiency, quantum efficiency, and then the second point is uh like you mentioned, the longer wavelength. Uh, so recently there are starting to have efforts uh to shift to longer wavelength so that not only the excitation is in the infrared region, but also the emission is also in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: So right now what sort of uh probes do you use for voltage? Are those the aneps or are they other kind of nanoparticles?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so I'm not as for this, um, we use genetic reporters, uh, something called ASAP and sometimes is uh some archam. So,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean there's a couple of different families of voltage reporters. None of them are perfect. Many of them are inverted, uh, meaning that, uh,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: that you have a decrease in fluorescence rather than an increase in fluorescence in response to some event that you're detecting. That's of course not great because the probes are also bleaching. And so kind of would much rather quantify an increase in fluorescence.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Some of them are based off of GFP, other are based off of other kinds of proteins and their modalities under development for uh really nice multiphoton excitation, but also single photon uh has been quite, you know, broadly uh used.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Voltage sensor imaging is super important for neuroscience because despite the dominance of really heavily engineered GFP based calcium sensors, we know that calcium reporting of neural activity is really limited. Uh, it's got really slow temporal kinetics, which helped us at first because we didn't have a good imaging methods to go faster.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, but it's slow, you know, it misses neuronal action potentials. It doesn't report hyperpolarization very well unless on a really slow time scale. Uh, it doesn't tell you very much about, you know, not nothing about sub threshold events, which is

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: you know, everything about how neurons compute is about sub threshold very interesting biophysics and integration across the, you know, unique and neuron type specific uh dendritic trees that they used to collect information with. Um,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I think uh um Jean Young's lecture yesterday is really showing a glimpse in the future of just how sophisticated some of these genetic reporters can become.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um maybe Carolyn bring you in as we've just sort of been focusing a little bit here on pure fluorescence, but photoacoustic is uh that's one of the

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: I was kind of my question as I was listening is that um, are we only thinking about deep tissue imaging in the context of optics and it seems like it's a very, you know, optics microscopy heavy group, but um, obviously thinking about our colleagues that work in other imaging modalities like MRI.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, you know, I do photoacoustics which is using um optics to excite to then ultrasound acoustics to receive. Um, you know, is there some other excitation that we should be thinking about beyond light since we know the limitations of light or

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: alternatively, I mean just to describe what how we get around the limitation in photoacoustic imaging is that

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: we are not worried about coherent focus light, you know, we're using scattered light for our imaging purpose.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um that said we still have depth limitations. You know, we're limited to to two to three centimeters. I would say. Um, but we still want to go deeper than that even obviously so that we can image clinically.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well that's quite impressive two to three centimeters that uh that's um

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Do you and that's not a problem for you? I mean I I read this all the time in the papers but

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: it's one thing to read it do do you can one regularly do biomedical

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we we so there's there's essentially two different strategies for photoacoustic imaging. There's optical resolution photoacoustic imaging and that those are the super impressive like vascular networks that you see in the papers. And then there's acoustic resolution. So what I do primarily is acoustic resolution.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: So, um, my spatial resolution is not going to be even close to what all the optical microscopists um can do. So I'm spatial resolution is more in the 100 to 200 micron.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I think um there is

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
